Comedy'My Three Angels'
Slated For Shriver Tonight
By GERRY SPANIER
"My Three - Angels," a comedy
guaranteed to fill Shriver Hall
with tumultuous laughter, will
again show up the acting abilities
of the members of the Barnstormers as they present this
work by Sam and Bella Spewack
tonight and tomorrow night at
8:30 p.m.
Taking place around Christmas-time, in the 1890's, at
Devil's Island, the comedy finds
three convicts, Dennis Donahue,
Warren Donohue, and Chuck
Davis at work for a kindly,
overly-helpful storekeeper, Jerry
Czarnicki. The convicts try to
cover up the losses that their
boss has incurred through his
giving away of his money.
"I expect this will be one of
our most successful efforts," said
Barnstormers President Ed Ross.
"We, have a good cast, a good
director and a good play."

Heading heavenwards, "My
Three Angels" Warren Donohue,
Chuck Davis and Dennis Donahue (in ascending order) bid
farewell to Mary Pat Waesche.

As everyone knows, the most serious problem facing American
colleges today is the shortage of parking space for students' cars.
Many remedies have been offered to solve this vexing dilemma.
For instance, it has been suggested that all students be required
to drive small foreign sports cars which can be carried in the
purse or pocket. This would, of course, solve the parking problem but it would make double dating impossible—unless, that
is, the boys make the girls run along behind the car. But that
is no solution either because by the time they get to the prom
the girls will be panting so hard that they will wilt their corsages.
Another suggested cure for our parking woes is that all
students smoke Marlboro cigarettes. At first glance this seems
an excellent solution because we all know Marlboro is the
cigarette which proved that flavor did not go out when filters
came in—and when we sit around and smoke good Marlboros
we are so possessed by sweet contentment that none of us
wishes ever to, leave, which means no gadding about which
means no driving, which means no parking problem.
But the argument in favor of Marlboros overlooks one important fact: when you run out of Marlboros you must go get
some more, which means driving, which means parking, which
means you're right back where you started.
Probably the most practical suggestion to alleviate the campus
in

MEMORIES. But with typical
Hopkins resourcefulness, I leafed
through my Abnormal Psychology textbook to the chapter on
amnesias and treatments of
same. Hypnosis was too dangerous and sodium pentothal too
expensive, so I settled for a combination of free-association and
desperate panic, to help me report on the magazine—sort of
-like taking an exam.
Well. It was a good issue, as
I recall. The cover showed a
group of tourists standing atop
Lover's Leap, but I can't remember whether they were just admiring the view below or preparing to join it.

young girls, according to the report. They develop dishpan
hands, social-worker 'smiles, and
bruised psyches. Then, just before they either collapse or adaPt
themselves to it, they are
whisked back into school for an
academic transfusion.
It seems that these young
Portia's must face eternally conflicting demands: "Adjust! Adjust!" screams the world outside. "Study! Study!" urges the
school. And the girls settle the
dispute the only possible way,
"Forget it. I'll get married.
Which is fine for them, but what
about the male college student
-thrown out upon the world? if
these charming, normal young
women have trouble adjusting to
the "world" after college, then
we have the same right. We face
the same conflict, but marriage is
no solution, because the eager
young wives will immediatelY
saddle their spouses with another
seek
shriek: "Seek status!
staths!" If anyone is curious
about what life is like outside, he
can get a hint of the shocking
truth in all its maladjustive
horror, in this article. At least,
that's the way I remember it.
SPACE. Reference is made
elsewhere to the men of the
Johns Hopkins Applied Physics
brainchild
Laboratory
whose
satellite was launched last week.
The importance of this achievement for us here cannot be overstated, since the University maY
have to do all its expanding on
the Moon or Mars if the sale of
Wyman Park does not materialize (don't laugh—we can't
build on Charles Street). We
must beware lest some rival
colonizers like the children of
Baltimore City beat us to the
Moon and convert every acre of
it into "much-needed" playground space. We would never
be able to wrest a square foot
away from them. If they can do
it on earth, they can do it on
the moon. The LIFE coverage,
I adinit, takes a slightly different
attack from this on recent advances in space exploration, but
we must keep in mind the implications of such moves for us.

Amazons? Vestal virgins? The

girls. A poignant article outlines
their trials and tribulations on a
sort of sabbatical vacation during
which they work (yes, work) in
a field related to their major.
They are weaned away from the
sheltered atmosphere of college
in short doses of exposure to the
demands and shocks of the "real
world." And the transplanting

By JOHN DOUP
The frosh lacrosse club seeks
Its first victory of the campaign
today against the Maryland
freshmen at College Park. The
young Terps, with a team composed of the top Baltimore prep
stars of 1959, led by high-scoring
Ray Altman of City College, are
heavily favored.
In their first game on March
25, the yearling Jays, hampered
by inexperience and lack of practice, bowed to Boys' Latin by a

score of 6-4. However, the fledglings have had five scrimmages
during the 4 week interval and
have shown constant improvement.

Coach Fred Smith points out
that this year's squad is in a very
unusual situation, since only
five of 26 squad members have
had any previous stick experience. The frosh have therefore
had the problem of learning the
game and playing it at the same
time.
The recent scrimmages with
Colgate, Baltimore Junior College, Virginia, Loyola High, and
Holy Cross have been very encouraging for Coach Smith, who
states that they "may have given
the boys much-needed game experience. The boys themselves,
though unpolished, have shown a

Also, the proposed building must
be an extension of the present
building rather than a separate
structure.
As a consequence of the proposed addition, the Biology Department hopes to increase the
number of graduate students
from 50 to 72 and the number of
post-doctoral fellows from 26 to
50. There will probably also be
a slight increase in staff members throughout the next few
years, it was announced.

Honor
Any students interested in
becoming members of the
Honor Commission should
submit their applications to
Warren Donohue, Box 114, as
soon as possible. The application must include name, box
number, class schedule and
picture if at all possible.

Comedy'My Three Angels'
Slated For Shriver Tonight
By GERRY SPANIER
"My Three - Angels," a comedy
guaranteed to fill Shriver Hall
with tumultuous laughter, will
again show up the acting abilities
of the members of the Barnstormers as they present this
work by Sam and Bella Spewack
tonight and tomorrow night at
8:30 p.m.
Taking place around Christmas-time, in the 1890's, at
Devil's Island, the comedy finds
three convicts, Dennis Donahue,
Warren Donohue, and Chuck
Davis at work for a kindly,
overly-helpful storekeeper, Jerry
Czarnicki. The convicts try to
cover up the losses that their
boss has incurred through his
giving away of his money.
"I expect this will be one of
our most successful efforts," said
Barnstormers President Ed Ross.
"We, have a good cast, a good
director and a good play."

Heading heavenwards, "My
Three Angels" Warren Donohue,
Chuck Davis and Dennis Donahue (in ascending order) bid
farewell to Mary Pat Waesche.

As everyone knows, the most serious problem facing American
colleges today is the shortage of parking space for students' cars.
Many remedies have been offered to solve this vexing dilemma.
For instance, it has been suggested that all students be required
to drive small foreign sports cars which can be carried in the
purse or pocket. This would, of course, solve the parking problem but it would make double dating impossible—unless, that
is, the boys make the girls run along behind the car. But that
is no solution either because by the time they get to the prom
the girls will be panting so hard that they will wilt their corsages.
Another suggested cure for our parking woes is that all
students smoke Marlboro cigarettes. At first glance this seems
an excellent solution because we all know Marlboro is the
cigarette which proved that flavor did not go out when filters
came in—and when we sit around and smoke good Marlboros
we are so possessed by sweet contentment that none of us
wishes ever to, leave, which means no gadding about which
means no driving, which means no parking problem.
But the argument in favor of Marlboros overlooks one important fact: when you run out of Marlboros you must go get
some more, which means driving, which means parking, which
means you're right back where you started.
Probably the most practical suggestion to alleviate the campus

By JOHN DOUP
The frosh lacrosse club seeks
Its first victory of the campaign
today against the Maryland
freshmen at College Park. The
young Terps, with a team composed of the top Baltimore prep
stars of 1959, led by high-scoring
Ray Altman of City College, are
heavily favored.
In their first game on March
25, the yearling Jays, hampered
by inexperience and lack of practice, bowed to Boys' Latin by a

score of 6-4. However, the fledglings have had five scrimmages
during the 4 week interval and
have shown constant improvement.

Coach Fred Smith points out
that this year's squad is in a very
unusual situation, since only
five of 26 squad members have
had any previous stick experience. The frosh have therefore
had the problem of learning the
game and playing it at the same
time.
The recent scrimmages with
Colgate, Baltimore Junior College, Virginia, Loyola High, and
Holy Cross have been very encouraging for Coach Smith, who
states that they "may have given
the boys much-needed game experience. The boys themselves,
though unpolished, have shown a
